clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Nap on Daytime Functioning in Primary School Students
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Short Daytime Nap on Neurocognitive Functioning and Behavior in Chinese Primary School Children

brief_summary.textblock: Previous studies showed that insufficient sleep has a negative impact on children's physical and psychological health. Napping was found to decrease sleepiness and improve daytime functioning in adults and adolescents. The effects of napping on children, however, is unknown. The current study aims to test the effects of short daytime classroom naps on daytime functioning and behaviour in elementary school children.

detailed_description.textblock: This study is an interventional study testing the effects of short daytime nap on children's cognitive functioning and daytime behaviour. Primary school children will be randomised to either experimental (nap) or control group (no nap) by class. Measurements include parent-report questionnaires, children's self-report questionnaires, and cognitive tasks.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Experimental group (with daytime classroom nap) versus control group (without nap)
study_design_info.masking_description: Assessors who are responsible for conducting the cognitive tests are blinded to the group allocation.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (sustained attention)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: Reaction time (ms) in psychomotor vigilance task

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (sustained attention)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: Lapses defined by reaction time (RT) more than 500ms in psychomotor vigilance task

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (inhibitory control)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: false alarm rate (%) in Go-no go task

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (inhibitory control)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: reaction time (ms) in Go-no go task

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (working memory)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: reaction time (ms) in match to sample task

primary_outcome.measure: Change in objectively measured cognitive performance (working memory)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
primary_outcome.description: accuracy in match to sample task

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Daytime sleepiness as measured by Pediatric Daytime Sleepiness Scale (PDSS). Higher scores suggest more sleepiness.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in daytime behaviour (emotional & behavioural problems)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Daytime behaviors as measured by Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaires (SDQ). Higher scores suggest more emotional and behavioural problems.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 1 (before napping), Day 1 (after napping), two weeks and two months after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Strengths and Weakness of Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity-symptoms and Normal-behaviors (SWAN). Higher scores suggest more severe ADHD symptoms

arm_group.description: The experimental group will be allowed to take a brief nap daily on school days during the study period.
The control group will not be allowed to take daily nap on school days during the study period.

intervention.description: Participants will be given 20-min nap opportunity in the classroom on a daily basis during school-days.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children from grade 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children ages 4 or younger, ages 15 or older
